decision_conditions: The Oak tree is situated in the front garden of 31 Copse Wood Way and can be seen along the road, The tree does not appear to have been pruned before and has an attractive, natural-looking crown typical of it's species.
Along with other nearby trees the Oak helps to provide a gradual transition of mature tree cover between the dwellings in Copsewood Way and the nearby Ruislip woods National Nature Reserve (NNR).

The tree contributes to local biodiversity, and significantly contributes to the amenity and arboreal / wooded character of the Copsewood Estate Area of Special Local Character. The tree has a very high amenity value.

The tree is growing to the North of the property and as a result the shading from this tree onto the property will be minimal and unlikely to increase with pruning. Currently there is no scope to thin the tree's crown by as much as 1/3rd. Thinning the crown would likely give many of the branches a top heavy 'lion's tail' appearance. The prosposed work would als
The removal of deadwood, dangerous / hanging branches and ivy:  This does not require the formal consent of the Council.
description: To carry out tree surgery, including a crown thin by 1/3 and crown lift to 3m, to one oak (T1 on application), within Area 1 on TPO 398.
